etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Henry McMurtrie (1793–1865). From French otarie from ancient Greek ὠτάριον little ear from ὠτ-, οὖς ear + -άριον, extended form of -ιον, diminutive suffix, so named with allusion to the animal's distinctive auricles

definitions: An eared seal (i.e. a sea lion or a fur seal); an otariid.
